> I do realise though that this means I do have to mentally block out the red
> tests/suites that are just those  not implemented, from those that are
> failing.
> 
> Maybe JUnit could be enhanced to have Amber tests for these situations?

I think that an exception should not define the state of the test 
(invalid/valid or nyi/valid) but that the state of the test should 
define what the exception means.

For example:
    public void testXYZ_failing() {
       /* test is nyi */
       throw new AssertionFailedError();
    }

tells you that this test is expected to fail.  The ouput of the runner 
could be:

..................
..............

failing: 10 (0 errors - 10 failures)

56 tests, 0 errors, 0 failures

For nyi tests it's certainly a "nice to have", but for other kind of 
tests it can be certainly very helpful.  let's take for example bug reports.

If your users send you bug reports in the form of JUnit tests, you don't 
have normally the time to fix them all right away (and it's especially 
the case in the Open Source World).  So what should you do with these 
reports?

- keep them and bugzilla:
    [+] the existing tests are clean (the rule "only commit if all the 
tests pass" applies)
    [-] the tests may not compile when you finally have the time to fix them
    [-] less attractive for new developers (OSS world)

- integrate them in your tests:
    [+] your bug reports are always in sync with your code
    [+] more attractive for newcomers (easier to pick up a test and 
debug it)
    [-] rule of "not committing if tests fail" does not apply.

AFAIK JUnit could easily be modified to support both options, the only 
question is: should it be done?

Other idea?
